awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unifying Science for Students: Investigating transfer within a coherent, interdisciplinary set of science courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This Exploration and Design project in the Engaged Student Learning track in the Improving Undergraduate Science Education program seeks to address the intractable concept of transfer of learning to new settings. A central assumption in most systems of education is that students will be able to apply knowledge and skills beyond the context in which they are originally learned and hence transfer their learning. Existing research studies indicate, however, that successful transfer is exceedingly rare. In this project, transfer will be examined within an existing series of undergraduate science courses intended to promote coherent understanding of energy in physics, chemistry, Earth science, and biology. Energy, a unifying concept important in most science disciplines, is central to scientific literacy and is an idea students should be able to apply to a variety of situations. The integrated curriculum presents energy coherently across disciplines, was designed on the basis of cognitive research, and has been extensively classroom tested at multiple institutions. The course sequence thus serves as a natural laboratory to investigate how much transfer is possible under highly favorable, yet still realizable, conditions. Unifying Science for Students will measure and describe transfer, as well as document the specific components of instruction that promote transfer. Special attention will be paid to understanding how to support transfer among students from traditionally underrepresented groups. Findings will contribute to the knowledge base of what works in supporting application of energy concepts across contexts, for all students.  This project may also help to establish the integrated course sequence as a national model for coherent, cross-disciplinary undergraduate science education. 

The integrated curriculum spans four courses: The Flow of Matter and Energy in Physical Systems, Earth Systems, Life Systems, and Chemical Systems. Unifying Science for Students will bring together expertise in physics, chemistry, biology, geology, and cognitive science at two institutions to add to the research base on transfer, using this course series. It will do so by: (1) evaluating the extent to which students successfully transfer understanding of energy in a coherent, constructivist-based sequence of science courses; (2) documenting the productive and problematic reasoning approaches that arise when students transfer ideas about energy to new contexts; (3) identifying instructional cues that facilitate transfer; and (4) investigating the impact of explicit instruction in metacognition on the understanding, retention, and transfer of energy concepts across disciplines.  Quantitative and qualitative methods will be employed to address these goals. A longitudinal study will generate quantitative measures of the transfer of energy concepts from the original learning context, physics, to a target domain, chemistry. Interviews, classroom observations, and analysis of written work will be used to describe what transfer "looks like" by developing a taxonomy of discipline-specific transfer attempts. Finally, a quasi-experimental study will investigate the impact of metacognitive writing assignments on transfer. The general and discipline-specific knowledge generated through this project will be situated to inform curriculum design so that transfer can become a more realizable goal in higher education.  The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program is providing co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader teacher preparation goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
The Unifying Science for Students (USS) project investigated cross-disciplinary learning of energy concepts within a science content course series for undergraduates studying to become K-8 teachers. This course series, which includes one course each in physics, geology, biology, and chemistry, has an explicit focus on matter and energy. Using the science education course series as a laboratory, the USS project consisted of three distinct studies which focused on cross-disciplinary learning of energy concepts. One of the major outcomes of this project was to define, and propose a framework for measuring, cross-disciplinary learning. Drawing upon theories of learning, transfer, and interdisciplinary reasoning, we have defined cross-disciplinary learning as a process of sequential learning in which students activate, transform, and integrate knowledge from different disciplines, combining previous learning with new learning in the service of constructing new knowledge within a specific discipline. This framework guided each of the three studies.


Study 1 asked, “To what extent can students successfully engage in cross-disciplinary learning of energy concepts?” We designed a quantitative approach, which involved a paired instrument strategy for assessing cross-disciplinary learning, to address this question. This strategy utilized two instruments, one in a physics context and the other in a chemistry context, both of which assessed students’ ability to apply the law of conservation of energy to different scenarios. The chemistry instrument incorporated some teaching narratives and unscored comprehension questions alongside the scored application questions, in order to focus that instrument on cross-disciplinary learning and not solely on understanding of energy. We administered the paired instrument set to over 1500 students from a range of different backgrounds in postsecondary science coursework, and used these data to support the validity of the instruments as well as to assess students’ ability to engage in cross-disciplinary learning in our sequence of science education courses. Although we do not have enough data from the original longitudinal design we developed, the trend in the data that we are so far seeing is that students in the SCED sequence generally do better on the instrument set the more SCED courses they take, supporting the hypothesis that a coherent course series can support cross-disciplinary learning. The paired instrument can be used to measure cross-disciplinary learning on the course or program level, or the overall approach can be adapted to other disciplines and/or learning goals.


Study 2 asked, “What difficulties do students encounter and what productive resources do they bring to bear when engaging in cross-disciplinary learning of energy concepts?” In this study, we developed three think-aloud interview protocols geared toward qualitatively assessing students’ cross-disciplinary learning; one each emphasizing geology, biology, and geology contexts. For comparison, each protocol also contained a scenario in a physics context. In each protocol, students were asked to construct scientific explanations for scenarios. We developed a conceptual resource-based coding scheme as well as a thematic analysis approach for analyzing the interview transcripts. We found: 1) Students were able to cite various forms of energy in their explanations, and that these forms, especially potential energy forms, were defined and used in unique ways in different disciplines; 2) Students often had difficulty attaching indicators and mechanisms to various potential energy forms; and 3) Certain types of cues helped students identify potential energy as being involved in the scenarios. These included cues to account for energy, to attach indicators to changes in energy, and cues to represent and model energy, especially using the particular type of energy diagram that all the science education courses used.  


Study 3 asked, “To what extent does explicit instruction in metacognition, in the form of targeted reflective writing, facilitate cross-disciplinary learning?” In this study we developed a set of teaching and learning materials to support students’ engagement with cross-disciplinary learning of energy.  We piloted these materials in two sections of the science education physics class.  Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we were not able to rigorously test these materials in multiple sections as we had originally planned. However, these materials can catalyze design of curricula emphasizing the connection of concepts across disciplines, for use in other course and program contexts.


The products and knowledge developed through the USS project was disseminated through multiple invited and contributed conference presentations to various groups of science educators and discipline-based education researchers. Three manuscripts, in various stages of preparation or publication, describe our cross-disciplinary learning framework, as well as results from Studies 1 and 2.
